Alright, I spent a good deal of time the past week putting this all together in a word document before I posted it here in its entirety. This thread seeks to challenge the current consensus that Jesus Christ was a historical figure. To do this, first we need to define what we mean by "Jesus Christ." I find that this is a very broad catchall phrase that can mean the god-man depicted in the NT Gospels to a shadowy figure standing behind layers of Q and other sayings source material. The first character, the god-man, can very easily be dismissed. That Jesus Christ never existed. 
 
 On the latter extreme, dismissing the shadowy figure that served as an inspiration for the stories about the god-man is a bit more difficult. But I would argue that with current scholarship we are on the cusp of dismissing that inspirational source for the Jesus story as well, not with the certainty that we dismiss the god-man Jesus Christ, but with a more likely than not certainty. 
 
 I think we (and defining "we" I mean those who care about history and interpreting the available evidence to argue to the best explanation) can pretty well dismiss any thought that someone named "Jesus Christ" preached in Galilee, traveled to Rome, created a disturbance in the Temple and was crucified by the Romans. That Jesus Christ simply never existed.
 
 So where do we start with this project? I will say this: not with Paul. Not with the Gospels. We know from Paul that Christianity was well-established throughout the Roman empire by the time of Paul, so we have to examine the millieu in which "Jesus Christ" emerged: Palestine of the first century, heavily influenced by Platonist philosophy, Greek mystery religions, and the weight of history on the Jewish nation. 
 
 So the start of Christianity does not begin with Jesus Christ at all, but with Jewish documents that pre-exist but foreshadow "Jesus Christ." Apologists consider these prophecies about Jesus Christ. Non-christians who argue for an HJ (Historical Jesus) seem to avoid discussing them altogether. But when we consider the emergence of early Christian thought in the first century, it is impossible to simply ignore the currents of thought that clearly presage Jesus. If we dismiss prophecy at work, then we are really left with an evolution of the idea of Jesus. 
 
 The state of current NT scholarship on Jesus Christ tends to ignore or dismiss this evidence altogether. The consensus that has developed around the idea of an historical Jesus is really built on the identification of layers of sayings that served as sources for the gospels. I'll discuss these later, but for now, let me say that in fact Q1, Q2, Q3 point more to a MJ (Mythical Jesus) than to a HJ (Historical Jesus). If these are layers of sayings added on over the years, then they are clearly not Jesus sayings. If we say then that the earliest layer, Q1, might be authentically Jesus, I'd say we have no way to show that. The sayings in Q1 could come from anywhere and just have been compiled into a "Jesus say" collection. The source for Q1 is so obscure that we can not draw out any positive statements to attribute them to an historical figure. In fact, many are probably derived from cynic/stoic sayings.
 
 So first: I think our best start when talking about the origins of christianity come from second and first century BCE Judaism. This is a time when hellenistic influences had strongly pervaded Palestinian culture. Greek gods were worshipped openly. The Maccabbeans seemed to fulfill the Messianic desires of the Jewish people and then ultimately failed, themselves tarnished by blasphemy. Josephus documents time and again, Jewish martyrs leading the people to doom at the hands of the Romans. It is in this millieu that the idea of the suffering servant merged with the platonist influenced idea of the Logos described by Philo. Let's start with Isaiah 52/53:

Note that the idea here isn't that this will happen in the future, but that it has happened. I would argue that Mark is dependent in part on Antiquities and Wars of Josephus and was probably not written much before 100 CE. Again, this interpretation is more consistent with the evidence. First, it is clear that the idea of human sacrifice for the purpose of redemption was deeply rooted from the beginning in the suffering servant motif. The high priest/Logos motif in Hebrews is especially strong and makes it one of the most interesting documents in the New Testament.
 
 So this is the logic of the system similar to the logic of the Dionysus cult which actually sacrificed a human stand-in for the god (later they would burn an effigy). The sacrifice was to be a human sacrifice--the core foundational belief of Christianity.

Heb 2:9 But we see Jesus, who was made a little lower than the angels, now crowned with glory and honor because he suffered death, so that by the grace of God he might taste death for everyone.

 Again, here, the idea is repeated: the suffering servant becomes Jesus Christ by his sacrifice.

Here we have no mention of Pontius Pilate, the Virgin Mary. We won't for many, many long decades. No one mentions "born of the Virgin Mary", "crucified under Pontius Pilate". Those are ideas that come much later in time.

 Second, referring back to Gal 4, we see Paul begin to compare the birth of Jesus Christ to Ishmael and Isaac:
 
Galatians 4:21 Tell me, you who want to be under the law, are you not aware of what the law says? 22For it is written that Abraham had two sons, one by the slave woman and the other by the free woman. 23His son by the slave woman was born in the ordinary way; but his son by the free woman was born as the result of a promise. 

 
 Now Paul says something very important:
24These things may be taken figuratively, for the women represent two covenants. One covenant is from Mount Sinai and bears children who are to be slaves: This is Hagar. 25Now Hagar stands for Mount Sinai in Arabia and corresponds to the present city of Jerusalem, because she is in slavery with her children. 26But the Jerusalem that is above is free, and she is our mother. 

 
 Here Paul takes these births, just a few verses later, to be figurative. The new Jerusalem, the kingdom of God, is our mother, just as it is the mother of Jesus Christ. There is no Virgin Mary, Bethlehem, Nazareth in Paul's view of the birth of Jesus.
 
 Finally, on this objection, note that Paul says God sent the "Spirit of his Son". Again, this points to something other than a Jesus Christ preaching in Galilean synagogues (there is a question as to whether there were synagogues in Galilee in the first half of the first century, before the destruction of the Temple, by the way).
 
 The second objection (I've encountered in the past) also stems from Galatians. In first chapter of Galatians, Paul explains:
 
Gal 1:18Then after three years, I went up to Jerusalem to get acquainted with Peter[b] and stayed with him fifteen days. 19I saw none of the other apostles-only James, the Lord's brother. 

 
 Note that this is 3 years after his conversion, possibly less than a decade after the alleged crucifixion of Jesus Christ. Since Paul refers to James as "the Lord's brother" this is often interpreted as meaning that James was a blood brother to the person "Jesus Christ." I don't think so. First, it is out of context within everything else Paul says about Jesus. Nowhere does he refer to any details of the life of Jesus on earth, but suddenly here is flesh and blood of the Savior. Second, if this were the brother of "Jesus Christ" one would think that Paul would give him the time of day, but he doesn't. Instead, he refers to Peter, James, and John as those "reputed to be pillars" (Gal 2:7) and tells us:
 
Gal 2:6As for those who seemed to be important-whatever they were makes no difference to me; God does not judge by external appearance-those men added nothing to my message. 

 
 Hardly the attitude one would take when meeting the brother of your Lord and Savior Jesus Christ. I think we can glean from Galatians, both the attitude here toward "those reputed to be pillars" and the later confrontation with Peter that Paul did not view them as people with any superior knowledge of Jesus Christ. Paul does not think they knew the living, human Jesus Christ. There is no evidence of that. I think Paul's designation of James as "the Lord's brother" is a title, an honorific, and it could be that Paul was using it sarcasticly. Certainly that is his tone toward Peter and James throughout most of Galatians. In fact, Paul makes clear that they all received their information in the same way:
 
1 Cor 15:3 For what I received I passed on to you as of first importance: that Christ died for our sins according to the Scriptures, 4that he was buried, that he was raised on the third day according to the Scriptures, 5and that he appeared to Peter, and then to the Twelve. 6After that, he appeared to more than five hundred of the brothers at the same time, most of whom are still living, though some have fallen asleep. 7Then he appeared to James, then to all the apostles, 8and last of all he appeared to me also, as to one abnormally born. 

 
 Note in this interesting passage that Jesus appears separately to Peter and Twelve and James and all the apostles, suggesting 2 different groups of people. Also note that he never refers to either Peter or James as "disciples" of Christ which would mean they were actual students of Jesus Christ, but as "apostles" or messengers of Jesus Christ. I think it is pretty clear that Paul has no knowledge of Peter, James, and John actually knowing a Jesus Christ who walked on earth.
 
 I think that takes care of the two most significant objections to my analysis of Paul. Now I want you to remember that I am arguing to the best evidence. When looking at Paul we have to look from within the context of Paul and the times he is writing. So when Paul says "born of woman" we tend to automatically picture the fairy tale story from Matthew and Luke about Mary and Joseph and hosts of angels. 
 
 But there is no reason for us to assume a priori that Paul has any knowledge of that. If we are trying to determine how these ideas developed, or at least entertaining the possibility that Jesus Christ was an evolved idea, then we must glean from Paul what we can without reference to later works that might impose their picture on our picture of Paul. I think that is very difficult to do. But I argue that if you do that successfully you see that Paul knows next to nothing about these Gospel stories and that would be awfully strange, a huge paradox.

This letter is traditionally dated to around 95-96 CE although all these dates are wildly tenative (another problem for providing a foundation on which an HJ can stand). So by this time, it is thought that the Gospel of Mark has been around for 25 years (I'll get into the dating of Mark later), Matthew a decade or so, maybe Luke has made its appearance and John out on his island is right now setting shaky pen to paper. All these things are happening, yet the powerful Bishop of Rome, writing his reprimand to the usurpers in Corinth is blissfully unaware of any of it. 
 
 The First Letter of Clement betrays no knowledge of the life and times of Jesus Christ. "Clement"'s vision of Christ has not advanced too far from Paul's, except that he does seem to believe in a vague sort of way that Jesus Christ lived and died on earth, not in some heavenly, mysitical realm, crucified by archons. But still, there is nothing about the passion, Pontius Pilate is yet to make his appearance in the Christ myth, golgotha, weeping marys, angels blazing (or simple young men) at tomb entrances are not in the awareness of Clement.
 
 I'll give some concrete examples, but think how extraordinary that is. This is after the supposed Gospels have been written, at least 2 of 4. This is one of the most prominent members of the developing Church of Rome writing an admonishment. Yet he does not attribute anything he has to say to any Gospel teaching or any teaching of Jesus!
 
 I think Clement shoots down 2 theories:
 
 1. Early dating of the Gospels. Clement would not have written as though the Gospels did not exist if he were aware of them.
 
 2. Existence of any form of concrete oral tradition about the life and times of Jesus. At most, awareness of Jesus's life on earth was vague with little concept of where and when things took place. Sayings have become attached to this legend, but the sources of those saying are obscure. 
 
 And Clement did have occasion to mention Jesus. In a list of the sufferings brought to righteous men of the Bible due to the jealousy of their foes (Clement is admonishing a group that has taken over the church in Corinth), after he has listed ancient examples: Aaron, Moses, Dathan, Cain and Abel, Clement says:
Clement 5:1
 But to stop giving ancient examples, let us come to those who became athletic contenders in quite recent times. We should consider the noble examples of our own generation.
 2 Because of jealously and envy the greatest and most upright pillars were persecuted, and they struggled in the contest even to death. 

 
 Here, what a perfect place to recount the passion of the Lord! Surely that story for centuries since its appearance has offered fodder for Christians, its image ubiquitous. Jesus brought to trial by the jealous Sanhedrin and convicted on trumped up charges? But no. Not a mention from Clement of the suffering of the earthly Jesus. Instead, his examples of "our generation" are Peter and Paul who have been dead and gone at least 30 years. 
 
 When Clement does refer to Jesus Christ, he nearly always references the Old Testament:
 
 
Clement 14:3
 We should treat one another kindly, according to the compassion and sweet character of the one who made us.
 3 For it is written, "Those who are kind will inhabit the land, and the innocent will be left upon it; but those who break the law will be destroyed from it." 

 
 Why not quote Jesus here? Who knows? But Clement instead turns to Proverbs and Psalms for his material. I would argue that it is because the Gospels do not exist at this time. Further, there is little knowledge about what Jesus said and did that has yet been developed. But there is some, so for instance, Clement says:
 
Clement 13:1
 ...We should especially remember the words the Lord Jesus spoke when teaching about gentleness and patience.
 2 For he said: "Show mercy, that you may be shown mercy; forgive that you that it will be forgiven you. As you do, so it will be done to you; as you give, so it will be given you; as you judge, so you will be judged; as you show kindness, so will kindness be shown to you; the amount you dispense will be the amount you receive." 

 
 Here it is in Matthew, spread out in verses over 3 chapters:
 
Matthew 5:7
 7Blessed are the merciful, 
 for they will be shown mercy. 
 
 Mathew 6:14-15
 14For if you forgive men when they sin against you, your heavenly Father will also forgive you. 15But if you do not forgive men their sins, your Father will not forgive your sins.
 
 Matthew 7:1-2
 1"Do not judge, or you too will be judged. 2For in the same way you judge others, you will be judged, and with the measure you use, it will be measured to you. 
 
 Matthew 7:12
 12So in everything, do to others what you would have them do to you, for this sums up the Law and the Prophets. 

 
 In Luke, this teaching has a more precise presentation, all occurring in Luke 6:31-38. 
 
 My feeling here is that Matthew 7:12 provides the answer: this was a common rehearsal of the Law and the Prophets that had become over time attributed to a teaching of Jesus Christ. Clement does not reference Matthew or Luke for this teaching and, in fact, in none of the manifestations of it, does it appear to have been quoted from the same source.
 
 Another instance of this is 46:8 which is also found in Matthew 26:24 and Luke 17:2. Again, here, though it would seem that Clement is quoting from these gospels, he makes no reference to them:
 
1 clem 46:7-8
 ...Remember the words of our Lord Jesus,
 8 for he said, "Woe to that person! It would have been good for him to not be born, rather than cause one of my chosen to stumble. Better for him to have a millstone cast about his neck and be drowned in the sea than to have corrupted my chosen."
 

 
 Here is the version in Matthew:
 
Matthew 26:23-24
 23Jesus replied, "The one who has dipped his hand into the bowl with me will betray me. 24The Son of Man will go just as it is written about him. But woe to that man who betrays the Son of Man! It would be better for him if he had not been born." 

 
 Here it is in Luke:
 
Luke 17:1Jesus said to his disciples: "Things that cause people to sin are bound to come, but woe to that person through whom they come. 2It would be better for him to be thrown into the sea with a millstone tied around his neck than for him to cause one of these little ones to sin. 3So watch yourselves. 
 "If your brother sins, rebuke him, and if he repents, forgive him. 4If he sins against you seven times in a day, and seven times comes back to you and says, 'I repent,' forgive him." 

 
 Again, it does not appear that Clement was quoting either of these passages. And his lead in "Remember the words..." signifies a bit of oral tradition rather a written a source which traditionally is referenced by the words "it is written". 
 
 Another important feature of Clement is his view of what "gospel" means. In past posts, I've pointed out that the word "gospel" did not originally mean stories about the life of Jesus or good news about the coming of the Kingdom of God, but that it was used in the Roman Empire to refer to news about the emperor, perhaps a proclamation that Emperor so-and-so has succeeded so-and-so. A gospel, then was viewed as a short pronouncement or proclamation. That is certainly how Paul uses it. Clement? The same as Paul:
 
1 clem 42:1
 The apostles were given the gospel for us by the Lord Jesus Christ, and Jesus Christ was sent forth from God. 

 
1 clem 47:1-3
 Take up the epistle of that blessed apostle, Paul.
 2 What did he write to you at first, at the beginning of his proclamation of the gospel? 

 
 Here Clement references the "gospel" but betrays no awareness of THE Gospels. The gospel for Clement like Paul is Christ crucified, risen and the coming of the kingdom of God. 
 
 
 But Clement does not stand alone in his ignorance about THE Gospels at this time. It is uniform throughout the Christian world. No one quotes from the Gospels until, in fact, Marcion's gospel in the mid-second century. Not until Iraneaus (around 180) is there any reference to the Gospels of Matthew, Mark, Luke and John. Another early reference is a syriac document from around 140 CE. So from all this I would conclude that the Gospels emerged around the turn of the second century. That as late as about 100 CE there was no knowledge of the details of the life of Jesus.
 
 Just in passing let me mention the Shepherd of Hermas. This is a document dated to the early second century. Like Clement, the Shepherd reveals nothing from the Gospels, but does refer to the parable of the master's vineyard. However, the parable is not cited to either an earthly Jesus (and in fact it comes to Hermas in a vision) or a Gospel and has different take than its later manifestations. The view in Shepherd is clearly adoptionist, a tendency that I mentioned in passing in the Paul post and comes through clearly also in Hebrews. Again, another example that there just was no story resembling the Gospel story by the turn of the second century that was known to important christians. (Shepherd by the way is thought to have been written by the brother of Pius, bishop of Rome.)
